headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Cummins Incorporated First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Ma
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Cummins Incorporated First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Mark Smith, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kylie. Good morning everyone and welcome to our teleconference today to discuss Cummins' results for the first quarter of 2016. Participating with me today are our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Linebarger; our Chief Financial Office
componenttext:
Thank you, Kylie. Good morning everyone and welcome to our teleconference today to discuss Cummins' results for the first quarter of 2016. Participating with me today are our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Linebarger; our Chief Financial Officer, Pat Ward; and our President and Chief Operating Officer, Rich Freeland. We will all be available for your questions at the end of the teleconference. 
Before we start, please note that some of the information that you will hear or be given today will consist of forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934. Such statements express our forecast, expectations, hopes, beliefs and intentions on strategies regarding the future. Our actual future results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements because of a number of risks and uncertainties. More information regarding such risks and uncertainties is available in the forward-looking disclosure statement in the slide deck and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, particularly the risk factor section of our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K and subsequently filed quarterly reports. 
During the course of this call, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures, and we'll refer you to our website for the reconciliation of those measures to GAAP financial measures. Our press release with a copy of the financial statements and a copy of today's webcast presentation are available on our website at cummins.com, under the heading of Investors and Media. 
Now I'll turn it over to our Chairman and CEO, Tom Linebarger.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for that warm introduction. Good morning everybody. I'll start with a summary of our first quarter results and provide an update on our outlook for the full year. Pat will then take you through more details on both our first quarter financial pe
componenttext:
Thank you for that warm introduction. Good morning everybody. I'll start with a summary of our first quarter results and provide an update on our outlook for the full year. Pat will then take you through more details on both our first quarter financial performance and our forecast for the full year. 
Revenues for the first quarter were $4.3 billion, a decrease of 9% compared to the first quarter of 2015. First quarter EBIT was $484 million or 11.3% of sales compared to $562 million or 11.9% in the same quarter last year. Our detrimental [ph] EBIT margin was 19% as the benefits of restructuring actions, improved quality, lower material costs all helped mitigate the impact of lower sales. 
Engine business revenues decreased by 10% year-over-year due to lower demand in North America heavy-duty truck market and weaker sales to global off-highway and Power Generation markets. 
Shipments of High Horsepower engines declined by 20% and reached the second lowest quarterly total in the past 12 years. EBITDA of 8.6% of sales declined from 9.7% a year ago as strong operational performance from our manufacturing plant and benefits from restructuring, material cost reduction initiatives and improved quality were offset by the lower impact -- or the impact, excuse me, of lower volumes. 
Revenues in our Components segment decreased 5% from a year ago, with lower demand North America more than offsetting growth in China. Sales in China increased by 27%, outpacing our end markets as we continue to capitalize on tighter emissions regulations and capture increased content and market share. EBIT of $173 million or 14% of sales declined from $195 million or 15% due to the impact of lower volumes and currency. 
Distribution revenues decreased by 1% compared to the first quarter of 2015. The negative impact of currency and weaker sales to off-highway markets more than offset the positive impact of acquisitions made in the second half of 2015. EBIT for the quarter of 6.5% improved from 6% a year ago with operational improvements more than offsetting the negative impact of currency. 
In the Power Generation business, revenues declined by 19% year-over-year, with weaker sales in most markets, especially in Asia and Latin America. EBIT declined from 7.2% to 5.6% as the impact of lower sales more than offset a 17% reduction in operating expenses. The first quarter is typically the weakest quarter for revenues in the Power Generation business and we do expect sales and margins to improve in subsequent quarters due to improving order intake in Europe and North America. 
Over the past 3 months, we've announced plans to further rationalize our manufacturing footprint, including the closure of an alternator facility in Mexico, a generator assembly plant in India and the exit of generator set assembly operations in Kent, England. These actions will start to generate savings in the second half of 2016, with additional savings in 2017 and 2018 and should help us stay ahead of any further risk of declining volumes. 
Now I will comment on some of our key markets, starting with North America. Our revenues in North America declined by 10% in the first quarter, due to weaker demand in on-highway markets, especially heavy-duty truck. Shipments to the North American heavy-duty truck market exceeded 16,000 units in the first quarter, a decrease of 33% from 2015 levels. First quarter market share was 29%. We have lowered our projection for full-year industry production to 210,000 units, at the midpoint of our guidance, down from our prior forecast of 22,000 units a slower freight activities has contributed to weak industry orders and higher dealer inventories. 
We currently expect our market share to be in the range of 27% to 30% for the year, down from our prior forecast of 30% to 33%, as Daimler has reduced the number of engines that it plans to order from Cummins and Navistar's market share has declined. 
In the medium-duty truck market, we delivered almost 22,000 engines in the first quarter, down 13% from last year. Our market share in the first quarter was 78%, down from 80% a year ago, only to complete our final shipments to Ford. We expect full-year industry production to be 123,000 units, down 1% compared to 2015 and our market share to be 75%, unchanged from our prior forecast. 
Our engine shipments to North American pickup truck OEMs increased by 29% in the first quarter. Shipments to Chrysler increased 9% to more than 34,000 units, the highest first quarter volume in 10 years. Sales also increased to Nissan following the launch of our 5-liter V8 engine in the fourth quarter last year. We currently expect our revenues in the pickup segment to increase by 12% in 2015[ph] , unchanged from our prior forecast. 
Our Engine revenues from the North American construction market decreased by 9% compared to the first quarter last year. While housing and commercial construction activity remains positive, demand for new equipment from rental companies has declined due to a slowdown in business in the oil and gas market. 
Power Generation revenues declined 4% in North America in the first quarter due to lower orders from data center customers. We expect full-year revenues in North America to be flat to up 2% as order rates have improved this year, following the weak close to 2015. 
Our international revenues declined by 8% year-over-year, with weaker sales in Latin America and Asia driving the decline. First quarter revenues in China including joint ventures were $767 million, a decrease of 5% due to the negative impact of the depreciation of the RMB against the U.S. dollar and weaker demand for power generation equipment. 
Industry demand for heavy and medium-duty trucks in China increased by 9% in the first quarter. We continue to increase our penetration at Foton which is now at 74%, up from 55% a year ago and at Dongfeng which is up more than 5% to 50%. Our overall market share was over 15% in the first quarter, down slightly from a year ago. As Dongfeng and Foton adopted a more cautious start to the year than some of their competitors, and under produced relative to the overall industry. We still expect our share will reach 80% for the year as our partners increase production sales more in line with the industry and our penetration continues to grow. 
We currently forecast full year industry sales to decline by 4%, unchanged from our previous forecast. Industry demand for the first quarter was stronger than expected. But visibility to demand in the second half is limited and we believe it is prudent to be cautious about market improvement. 
Shipments of our light-duty engines in China grew 9% in the first quarter compared to 3% decline for the overall market, as we increased penetration at Foton, displacing local competitor engines. Our share of the overall market reached 7% in the first quarter, up from 6% a year ago. We currently project industry sales to decline by 4% for the year, again, unchanged from 3 months ago. 
Our Power Generation revenues decreased by 27% year-over-year compared to a strong quarter a year ago. Sales weakened in the second half of 2015 as the industrial economies slowed and we have not seen any signs of improvement yet. Industry sales of excavators in China increased by 15% in the first quarter as OE dealers pushed sales of Tier 2 inventory ahead of the transition to Tier 3 emission standards and came into force in April. 
Overall numbers of excavators sold though remains low, and while there is little downside risk left, there is no obvious catalyst for significant growth in the near term. 
Full-year revenues in China across all segments including joint ventures are expected to be flat for the year consistent with our view 3 months ago with no major changes to any of our market assumptions. 
First quarter revenues in India including joint ventures were $390 million, up 7% year-over-year, primarily due to recovery in the Indian truck market. Industry demand in the truck market increased 25% compared to the first quarter a year ago as the economy continues to improve. Our market share in the first quarter was 38%, down from 39% due to stronger growth in sales of vehicles below 10% -- excuse me, below 10 tons in weight where our penetration in the market is lower. We now expect industry truck production to increase 10% for the year, up from our prior forecast of 8% growth. 
Power Generation revenues in India declined 1% in the first quarter with a weaker rupee offsetting 3% growth in volumes. We currently project full-year revenues, including joint ventures to be flat to up 2% with higher domestic volumes, largely offset by the depreciation of rupee against the U.S. dollar. 
First quarter revenues in Brazil were $72 million, down 42% from the first quarter last year, with the economy in recession and the real have been depreciated a further 16% against the U.S. dollar. Industry truck production fell 36% year-over-year while our engine shipments declined 35%. Revenues in all of our businesses were lower than a year ago due to the economic challenges in the region. We currently expect a full-year decline of 20% in industry truck production, with slightly easier comparisons to come in the second half of the year. 
Let me now make a few comments on High Horsepower markets. As I said in my opening remarks, volumes are extremely weak, with the first quarter's volumes down 20% due to lower demand in commercial marine, mining and power generation markets. New orders in the U.S. oil and gas market are very scarce. 
We expect full-year shipments of high-horsepower engines to decline by 6%, helped by growth in sales of our new QSK95 liter engine and easier comparisons in the second half of the year. We are very pleased to receive EPA Tier 4 final certification for our QSK95 engine for rail applications recently, allowing us to win some important business in the high-speed passenger rail market. 
In summary, we currently expect company revenues to decrease between 5% and 9% for the year, unchanged from 3 months ago. We did lower our outlook for heavy-duty truck production in North America, offset by an additional North American distributor acquisition and a less negative impact from currency in our forecast from 3 months ago. We expect EBIT to be in the range of 11.6% to 12.2% for the year, consistent with our prior forecast. We've made solid progress in executing our cost reduction plans in the first quarter and every organization throughout Cummins remains focused on driving further productivity and cost improvements. 
As one example, starting in April, we combined our Power Generation segment and High Horsepower Engine business into a newly formed segment called Power Systems. This reorganization will consolidate two businesses that are already strongly interdependent and will allow us to streamline business and technical processes to accelerate innovation in those markets, to grow market share and more efficiently manage our supply chain and manufacturing operations. [indiscernible] content previously leader of the Engine business is now leading the new Power Systems segment and [indiscernible] as the remaining Engine business. [indiscernible] and Tony Satterthwaite will continue to lead Components and Distribution segments, respectively. 
Finally, we returned $745 million to shareholders in the first quarter through dividends and the execution of our accelerated share repurchase program, consistent with our plan to return approximately 75% of our operating cash flow to shareholders in 2016. Thank you for your interest today. 
Now I'll turn it over to Pat, who will cover our first quarter results and full-year guidance in more detail.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning everyone. First quarter revenues were $4.3 billion, a decrease of 9% from a year ago, with currency movements reducing our sales by 3%. Sales in North America which represents 61% of our first quarter revenues declined 1
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning everyone. First quarter revenues were $4.3 billion, a decrease of 9% from a year ago, with currency movements reducing our sales by 3%. 
Sales in North America which represents 61% of our first quarter revenues declined 10% from a year ago, due primarily to lower demand in North American truck markets and continued weakness in industrial markets. International sales declined by 8% as a result of lower demand in Power Generation and industrial markets and the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar. 
Gross margins were 24.6% of sales, a decline of 80 basis points from a year ago. Lower volumes and an unfavorable product mix were partially offset by improvements in material costs and warranty expenses and the benefits from the restructuring actions. 
Selling, admin and research and development expense of $656 million or 15.3% of sales decreased $56 million from a year ago after taking restructuring actions in the fourth quarter of last year. This was 20 basis points higher as a percent of sales due to lower revenues. 
Joint venture income of $72 million increased by $4 million compared to a year ago, results in the first quarter a year ago included an impairment of an investment in the North Highway joint venture which did not repeat. 
Earnings before interest and tax were $484 million or 11.3% of sales for the quarter compared to 11.9% of sales last year and this equates to a detrimental [ph] EBIT margin of 19%. 
Net earnings for the quarter were $321 million or $1.87 per diluted share compared to $387 million or $2.14 per share from a year ago. And the effective tax rate for the quarter was 28.4%. 
I will now highlight the performance of the individual operating segments during the first quarter. In the Engine segment, revenues were $2.3 billion, a decrease of 10% from last year. Industrial revenues declined by 13% from weak global demand for engines in marine, mining and oil and gas markets. On-highway revenues decreased 8% as production in the North American heavy-duty truck market declined compared to a year ago. Segment EBIT was $200 million or 8.6% of sales compared to 9.7% last year. The benefits of the restructuring actions, material cost savings and lower warranty expense were more than offset by lower volumes and an unfavorable product mix, primarily from a reduction in North American heavy and medium-duty truck volumes and a 20% reduction in high-horsepower engine shipments. For the Distribution segment, first quarter revenues were $1.5 billion, a decrease of 1% compared to the prior year. Foreign currency movements negatively impacted sales by 4% while organic sales declined by 5% with lower sales in North American off-highway markets more than offsetting growth in China and in Europe. Acquisitions added 8% to revenues. EBIT margins for the quarter increased from 6% to 6.5%, despite a 70 basis point unfavorable impact from foreign currency. Excluding the currency impact, margins improved by 120 basis points due to the benefits of restructuring, a stronger mix of aftermarket revenues and positive pricing. 
The Components segment recorded sales of $1.2 billion, a decrease of 5% from a year ago. Sales in China increased in the first quarter by 27%, which helped partially offset the decline from lower heavy-duty truck production in North America and the negative impact of foreign currency. Segment EBIT was $173 million or 14% of sales compared to 15% of sales a year ago as lower volumes, unfavorable pricing and currency more than offset the benefits of material cost reductions and restructuring actions. 
In the Power Generation segment, first quarter sales were $550 million, down 19% from last year. International sales declined 27%, with Asia and South America experiencing the largest declines year-over-year due to the small piece of investment in infrastructure projects. EBIT margins were 5.6% in the quarter, down from 7.2% last year. The benefits from the restructuring actions and lower material costs partially offset the impact of the volume decline and helped keep detrimental margins to 14%. 
For the company. Cash flow from operations was $263 million, better than the same quarter last year by $19 [ph] million due to lower working capital requirements as sales declined. As we indicated at the beginning of the year, we plan to return approximately 75% of cash generated from operations to our shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases this year. 
During the first quarter, we repurchased 4.9 million shares, primarily resulting from the previously announced $500 million accelerated share repurchase program and we made dividend payments totaling $170 million, up from $140 million a year ago. Our cash and marketable securities balance declined in the quarter by $537 million, primarily due to the share repurchases, the increased dividend payments of $170 million and capital expenditure of $71 million. 
As Tom mentioned, our guidance for our full-year performance is unchanged from 3 months ago. We are projecting total company revenues to be down 5% to 9% in 2016, lower levels of production in the North American on-highway markets, reduced demand globally for off-highway and Power Generation equipment and negative impact of currency movements will drive the majority of the reduction in revenue. 
We expect some offset from introduction of new products and increased revenue from distributor acquisitions. We expect EBIT margins of between 11.6% to 12.2% for 2016 and this compares to 12.5% for the full year 2015 excluding the restructuring and impairment charges and represents a decremental EBIT margin of 25%. 
Benefits from material cost savings, restructuring and other actions will help mitigate the impact of lower volumes. Joint venture income are still expected to be flat compared to 2015. We anticipate operating cash flow performance in 2016 will be within our long-term guidance range of 10% to 15% of sales. And capital expenditures are expected to be in the range of $600 million to $650 million in 2016. As Tom just discussed, effective April, we reorganized the company into new operating segments. We will issue restated results for the first quarter of 2016 and results for 2015 and 2014 to reflect our new operating segments before we report second quarter results. We will issue [indiscernible] full-year guidance for each of the new operating segments [indiscernible] before we report second quarter results. And just to confirm, our current full year guidance for the company is unchanged from 3 months ago. 
Now let me turn it back over to Mark.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with BMO.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with BMO.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could break out the impact of the warranty? The warranty change in the quarter? And are we getting toward more normalized levels? Or is that going to be a number that continues to come down?
componenttext: I wonder if you could break out the impact of the warranty? The warranty change in the quarter? And are we getting toward more normalized levels? Or is that going to be a number that continues to come down?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me answer that one. So warrant in the quarter was 2.2% of sales for the company. That was down from 2.6% last year. We're very comfortable with our full year guidance of 2% and we are right on track with that. So no real difference of what we tal
componenttext: Yes, let me answer that one. So warrant in the quarter was 2.2% of sales for the company. That was down from 2.6% last year. We're very comfortable with our full year guidance of 2% and we are right on track with that. So no real difference of what we talk about 3 months ago, Joel, with regards to our outlook for warranty and improvements that we're seeing in the quality of our products throughout the company.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just sort of a bigger picture question, it seems like PowerGen in general has been declining for kind of 5 years or so. Are we getting toward the end of that process? Or do you think there's still pockets of weakness out there that are going to
componenttext: Okay. And just sort of a bigger picture question, it seems like PowerGen in general has been declining for kind of 5 years or so. Are we getting toward the end of that process? Or do you think there's still pockets of weakness out there that are going to last for the next 2 years or so?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question, Joe. I don't really know the answer for sure. But we're certainly been declining for much longer than we expected. I think that's why you've seen us take a succession of actions as opposed to just one bigger one which in retrosp
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question, Joe. I don't really know the answer for sure. But we're certainly been declining for much longer than we expected. I think that's why you've seen us take a succession of actions as opposed to just one bigger one which in retrospect, would have been better. But I -- we are of course preparing, as you can tell from these actions for continued weakness for some time. I think that's why we decided to take further actions in the business. When we did our restructuring in the fourth quarter, we did much more out of the Power Generation segment. We've now taken some plant capacity -- significant plant capacity out now with these 3 closures. So we are anticipating that we may be weak for some period. Hopefully, it improves faster than that. But we're prepared for it now after watching it decline for quite some time. Joel, if I could just add, the combination of our segments also, I think our gives us the opportunity now to begin the share overhead, drive improvement and efficiency in our processes between the large engine and the PowerGen business, which we think, not only will help us in this tough time, but as the market springs back, we'll be able to capture more share and respond more quickly. So we think it's good for the short run to reduce cost but also, it drives productivity and launch and ramp up processes and get much better in the future.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joel, just one more comment. You're right, Tom, the overall markets, we're not too optimistic on. But we are restructuring like we talk about. But also creating some of our own growth opportunities. So most of the QSK95 sales that we have are into the Pow
componenttext: Joel, just one more comment. You're right, Tom, the overall markets, we're not too optimistic on. But we are restructuring like we talk about. But also creating some of our own growth opportunities. So most of the QSK95 sales that we have are into the Power Generation market. And they're into places that we weren't there before. We're trying to grow share at a time when the market are low and we're having some good success.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Stephen Volkmann with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Stephen Volkmann with Jefferies.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe let's just go one step further with that line of questioning and you'd talked about, Tom, the margins in PowerGen getting better sequentially, I guess, on the back of the restructuring that you've done already. If the markets don't recover and sort
componenttext: Maybe let's just go one step further with that line of questioning and you'd talked about, Tom, the margins in PowerGen getting better sequentially, I guess, on the back of the restructuring that you've done already. If the markets don't recover and sort of stay in this depressed period situation, where do you think these margins can kind of normalized just based on what you've done so far?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have some work to figure that out, Steve. Of course, we're, as you know, we talked about trying to get back to double-digit margins even in weaker market. The markets have clearly fallen far more than any of us anticipated and we've now taken a se
componenttext: Yes, we have some work to figure that out, Steve. Of course, we're, as you know, we talked about trying to get back to double-digit margins even in weaker market. The markets have clearly fallen far more than any of us anticipated and we've now taken a set of actions that we think, normalizes us to these volumes. But we have some work to do to figure out where we think we can get margins at these levels. Clearly, it would help a bunch if revenues stabilized and stopped dropping. But we are -- it won't take us long to figure that out. The reason we still have work to do is, as you know, we just combined the segments. We just figured out -- we were just now eliminating some of the capacity. And the comparison like-for-like will be a little complicated given the combination segments. But expect us to be figuring that out pretty quickly and be able to set guidance for what the combined segment is and where we can take that in the future. But we're targeting all our segments at double digit margins even in tough times. So we're trying to figure out how to get there again. There's no question that right now, we are not there and we've got work to do to get there.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And my follow-up is just more on the heavy-duty truck side. Can you just tell us what you're seeing relative to cadence as we go through the quarter? I assume we'll sort of march down again here in the second quarter. But then what happ
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And my follow-up is just more on the heavy-duty truck side. Can you just tell us what you're seeing relative to cadence as we go through the quarter? I assume we'll sort of march down again here in the second quarter. But then what happens in the second half. If you have any visibility there, does the thing stabilize? Does it turn up to a little toward the end of the year? Do we just kind of continue the glide flow?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the way we're looking at, what's implied in our guidance, actually was some more downward pressure in the second half of the year. So if you just look at where we were in Q1, that would be a 2 24 market if you just multiply that by 4. And so I think ac
componenttext: So the way we're looking at, what's implied in our guidance, actually was some more downward pressure in the second half of the year. So if you just look at where we were in Q1, that would be a 2 24 market if you just multiply that by 4. And so I think actually, Q2 holds in okay. And I just -- past history says, that with backlog as low as it is, that we'll start to see some reductions in production in the second half of the year as we need more order boards, more [indiscernible]. That is a normal reaction that we see. So that's what we're putting into, we've taken the guidance down to $200 million to $220 million from the $220 million range before, potentially some back end. But most of the reductions happened. We're down 33% already Q1 to Q1. And so most of the reduction is in place for what we saw in Q1.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I'm wondering if you can update us on your plans for the distribution back-office integration now that you're on the tail end of wrapping up the acquisitions. Over what time frame are you looking for to complete the back-office integration at this po
componenttext: Tom, I'm wondering if you can update us on your plans for the distribution back-office integration now that you're on the tail end of wrapping up the acquisitions. Over what time frame are you looking for to complete the back-office integration at this point? And can you just celebrate us on the magnitude of cost savings opportunities we should look for when that plays out?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead and take that, Tom. So the piece that's behind is or a lot of it is most the back-office work has been done. And so we have a little more integration work to do there. But some of the bigger ones are still in front of us. So the distribution we t
componenttext: Go ahead and take that, Tom. So the piece that's behind is or a lot of it is most the back-office work has been done. And so we have a little more integration work to do there. But some of the bigger ones are still in front of us. So the distribution we talked about, we have 15 distribution centers. We want to go to much smaller. 2 in place, we'll put 3 more in place this year. And so by over the next couple of years, we'll get that savings. The purchasing savings, which is to build and we've got a really good purchasing process, you've seen the results we had in the business that are driving cost down, we're just now beginning that one. So we talked about getting $100 million in synergies, kind of maybe 40 to 50 of it in cost and the rest in sales. We're just really getting started. Were probably a quarter way through that on the cost side and more to come over the next couple of years.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jerry, I will just add that the processes to do the back-office work, we have now sent all those in place. There still some fall through work to do. But as Rich said, it's really now just a little bit of just -- it just fall through on making sure tha
componenttext: And Jerry, I will just add that the processes to do the back-office work, we have now sent all those in place. There still some fall through work to do. But as Rich said, it's really now just a little bit of just -- it just fall through on making sure that all that HR processes are working out and we're still acquiring the distributors. So [indiscernible] we acquired, we got to do them again. The opportunities are still in front of us. So we've actually had to go negative before you got positive. We've added cost in various processes to make it, to make sure that everybody is on the same pace system, the pension system. So we're going to see the benefits really starting to flow now. So we're pretty excited about those and both from a sales and support and service point of view for customers but also for our, on the cost and return side, which Rich talked to you about.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And Pat, can you talk about where engine margins were in the quarter relative to your internal expectations? Looks like decrementals were at 25%? I think the full-year guide at the midpoint would imply a 17% decremental of improvement. So
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And Pat, can you talk about where engine margins were in the quarter relative to your internal expectations? Looks like decrementals were at 25%? I think the full-year guide at the midpoint would imply a 17% decremental of improvement. So is that in line with the plan and I guess what's the offset to the weaker volumes to heavy-duty truck based on the new market and market share forecast?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was really pleased with how the Engine segment came out in the quarter. I think decremental, my number is [indiscernible] 20% EBIT margin. Decremental EBIT margin for the quarter which in the face of a 33% reduction in North America heavy-duty truck vol
componenttext: I was really pleased with how the Engine segment came out in the quarter. I think decremental, my number is [indiscernible] 20% EBIT margin. Decremental EBIT margin for the quarter which in the face of a 33% reduction in North America heavy-duty truck volumes and a 20% reduction in high-horsepower, I think, is a very, very good performance. Clearly, we're seeing benefits from material cost. We're seeing the benefits from the lower warranty expenses. I was talking to Joel about a few moments ago and the restructuring actions in the engine business took in the fourth quarter and the results are lower SAS spend I think it's all helping to keep those decrementals below what you normally be an acceptable looking for them. So I think we're off to a pretty good start this year.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the comps are easier as you pointed out in the coming quarters? Do you think get at the midpoint will apply better decrementals than first quarter?
componenttext: And the comps are easier as you pointed out in the coming quarters? Do you think get at the midpoint will apply better decrementals than first quarter?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you look at the engine segment last year, I think we got to the fourth quarter, it was a very difficult fourth quarter for us. So the second half I would expect to see a little bit better performance year-over-year.
componenttext: Yes, I think if you look at the engine segment last year, I think we got to the fourth quarter, it was a very difficult fourth quarter for us. So the second half I would expect to see a little bit better performance year-over-year.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple more questions on power gen and high-horsepower. Can you talk about how comfortable you feel that the inventory level and what's in the channel in both of the segments? And as I think about the restructuring, you've announced in combining th
componenttext: Just a couple more questions on power gen and high-horsepower. Can you talk about how comfortable you feel that the inventory level and what's in the channel in both of the segments? And as I think about the restructuring, you've announced in combining those segments, does that imply you think things could be, take another leg down? Could '17 potentially be up? I'm just trying to think if there's any read through with regards to what you're doing and what that means for what -- with how you're thinking about demand if you're more negative or positive? And that I guess my second question relates to market share on the heavy-duty truck side. You brought that down. Again, you talked about Navistar, you talked about Freightliner. Tom, confidence level in your longer term market share goals in North America heavy-duty truck with I think PACCAR saying a couple of weeks ago, their addressable market is now I think 80% to 85% versus before they were targeting a 50% market share. Thanks.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jamie. So I'm going to let Rich talk about inventory and heavy-duty truck. But again, just going back to the high-level question about when we get -- we do think there's more downside to come on the PowerGen side and then the large engine side gen
componenttext: Thanks, Jamie. So I'm going to let Rich talk about inventory and heavy-duty truck. But again, just going back to the high-level question about when we get -- we do think there's more downside to come on the PowerGen side and then the large engine side generally. But we decided to do is prepare ourselves for that potential outcome. We just don't know. The truth is we don't know if there's more downside to come. We do not see obvious signs of turnaround today. And so what we decided to do with this last set of actions, both in terms of the restructurings in Q4, the manufacturing footprint reduction and the combination of this and reorganization of these businesses to prepare ourselves for whatever is in front of us. That is what we are committed to do and that's what we're doing. And we've said that along, would be to take more actions, will take them. So these are an example of that. So we don't know what's going to happen in the future but we feel more prepared to deal with it whatever it is and feel like we've got our cost structure in place for what the business is now and again, if it's gets a lot worse, we'll figure that out and take action when we need to. But we really like the actions we've taken here that's better positioning us for a really really challenging market that exists today. And Rich, can you talk about inventory question?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take your last question first, Jamie and then I'll get to the high-horsepower inventory. So the long-term view on share, let me just repeat what I think is going on the market today with we see is we took that down as we saw our shares [indiscernib
componenttext: Let me take your last question first, Jamie and then I'll get to the high-horsepower inventory. So the long-term view on share, let me just repeat what I think is going on the market today with we see is we took that down as we saw our shares [indiscernible] and we forecast [indiscernible] down. But I think in the environmental excess capacity, we're clearly seeing more pressure to utilize internal resources and more incentives and discounting to do that. We also have seen some modest increase in Navistar this year. Again, nothing major but actually seen that go down. So those 2 things were behind the immediate change we put in place. Our approach, we are going to stay disciplined. We're not going to chase share with discounting. The products performing well and so we're going to continue to just sell that [indiscernible] a customer to get that back. at the same time, align our cost and deliverability financials in this environment. I think longer-term, as we think about the share, our view is it's still a 50% [indiscernible] 50% [indiscernible] market, okay? So that's -- and today, we compete really with the 15-liter product. And that was part of our announcement that we made in New York that we will be bringing the medium [indiscernible] to the market in 2017 to compete on the other end where we used to have kind of [indiscernible] product were going to have a terrific product down there at that end. So we see our share with PACCAR kind of in that 50% or 57% range now. That market tends to be a little more big board than medium board. So we feel from -- horsepower range, 13-liter products can over a large, larger part of the horsepower range. So just the right product in certain cycle and the customer kind of draws that to more 50-50. So that's what kind our guidance kind of looking forward.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on the inventory side, I'll let Rich comment more, we don't feel any concern about our inventory. High-horsepower engines we produced the demand, it is a really easy thing to look at. And we don't have any issues with that. And gensets, the same t
componenttext: I think on the inventory side, I'll let Rich comment more, we don't feel any concern about our inventory. High-horsepower engines we produced the demand, it is a really easy thing to look at. And we don't have any issues with that. And gensets, the same thing. In our distribution network, we also don't have extra inventory. We have been planning well. But the market has been down for some time. There's not a big -- there wasn't a big shift. The biggest concern, I think in the market place, really, is unused equipment. It's where our people and equipment. The mining market, this is an issue, and the oil and gas market, it's an issue. And what that means is that the business starts to pick up, they will be a little before we start to see the kind of equipment orders that we like to see when that business picks up. That's just the reality of what we see in some of these markets. And so that's what we're planning for. But in our system, our inventory levels are as they should be for this level of business.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan from JPMorgan.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-up questions. I know you won't guide for 2017 and that's not the purpose of this question. But can you talk a little bit about the heavy-duty North America on-highway side? Do you see 2016 as kind of a midcycle slowdown that we jus
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-up questions. I know you won't guide for 2017 and that's not the purpose of this question. But can you talk a little bit about the heavy-duty North America on-highway side? Do you see 2016 as kind of a midcycle slowdown that we just took too much inventory and we need to take that up and next we will be a more normal year? Or are you seeing cracks in the fundamentals that I think you addressed somewhat with the unused idle trucks that are out there. But just your kind of philosophical thinking on 2017 for on-highway?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The way I would answer that, the actual amount of freight moving is pretty reasonable, especially if you're in the consumer side, the housing side, the [indiscernible] side, some of the industrial [indiscernible] are down. But the freight actually, most o
componenttext: The way I would answer that, the actual amount of freight moving is pretty reasonable, especially if you're in the consumer side, the housing side, the [indiscernible] side, some of the industrial [indiscernible] are down. But the freight actually, most of the indicators looks pretty good. What we had last year, we shipped -- the backlog came down 60,000 units. So we shipped 60,000 units the backlog last year. And that's just not this year. so I just read more of a normal replacement cycle right now which is in kind of the 220 to 240 range. I think, this year potentially could be lower because backlog's are pretty low. And it's hard to run flat. There's just no visibility. I think what we see, what projecting in light, and again, not that we have a great insight. It just happened in our cycles is production rates come down a bit in the second half of the year to build up a little bit of backlog. And then I would look -- then you're back to kind of macro economic for 2017, which your guess is as good as mine. But right now, the general freight looks pretty good.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ann, my comment about unused equipment which is really in the high-horsepower market and not about trucks and really, just to add to Rich comments, the only real negative on the freight side has been there's -- the oil and gas business down. And they
componenttext: And Ann, my comment about unused equipment which is really in the high-horsepower market and not about trucks and really, just to add to Rich comments, the only real negative on the freight side has been there's -- the oil and gas business down. And they do buy a lot of trucks and in and around that market, there's a lot of trucks. You know the currencies are strong. So some of the exporters have been down. But that's been true for a while. That's not really changing very much. So the productivity that we've seen has been pretty steady as Rich said. So I think it is normalizing. We'll see obviously the macro economy in the U.S. I think will be the primary driver of where the see further reductions from here or whether we kind of stabilize and hang out at the levels in the second half on to 2017.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess I would share your view in that. So I appreciate that. And just a follow-up on I think when you were at our conference in March, there's some discussion that if there were any upside risks, this year will be made to the JV income. Can you jus
componenttext: Yes, I guess I would share your view in that. So I appreciate that. And just a follow-up on I think when you were at our conference in March, there's some discussion that if there were any upside risks, this year will be made to the JV income. Can you just talk about the pluses and minuses, what you're seeing in the joint ventures?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the [indiscernible] and I'll let Pat and Rich add. But the orders coming on China. There was a really strong quarter in China in the first quarter but I think there's some signs that things maybe good and improving and we're just remaining a
componenttext: Yes, I think the [indiscernible] and I'll let Pat and Rich add. But the orders coming on China. There was a really strong quarter in China in the first quarter but I think there's some signs that things maybe good and improving and we're just remaining a little cautious. So again, we left our forecast where it was and it's partially because we've just seen China promise better and beat the market, not be that strong the rest of the year, couple of years in a row so just want to be prudent and watch and see as see a couple of quarters before we really called an upside and also, just fundamentals don't look that much different. So I think that's the place where maybe, if things are improving, as some people suggest, we could have some upside in JV income there. But right now, our view is we're just -- we think we're pretty -- we're going to stay where we are from the point of view of forecasting. And on the off-highway side, maybe it's the opposite. It's not that things are great now. But I just feel like it's weak markets all over the place. And so maybe there's a little bit of downside still on off-highway. But again, I -- there's not much to go. The good news is we're selling there's not much to go. But there a lot of a lot of equipment and a lot of challenge in those markets. So again, I think we're pretty balanced on our forecast. I think our JV income line is pretty well-balanced and I believe where it is. But Rich, do you have anything to add?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think from a market standpoint, 100% agree. And I think just our position in that market, I mean, couple of positive things to feel good about. One is the reinforcement for the [indiscernible] were pretty good and probably better than what I would have
componenttext: I think from a market standpoint, 100% agree. And I think just our position in that market, I mean, couple of positive things to feel good about. One is the reinforcement for the [indiscernible] were pretty good and probably better than what I would have guessed, even a year ago as we introduced them, which is good for us. And second, we saw the growth in market shares. We've displaced competitive engines, especially with Foton with the ISF and ISG engine. And these engines are doing a terrific job. And Steve here, Steve talked about revolutionary. And the main fact are, just are -- they're lighter weight, they're high-performance, they don't break down I mean, just one number, the RSG engine is 150 pounds per liter and all the competitive engines are for 200. And so they're just engines, it's a different market where the old model was you had an engine that was easy to fix, because if they broke, their parts were not expensive. We're changing the market here with an engine that you had to get into and you don't had to change and have telematics on it. And so we had to rapid rise we're just displacing. Now are going to be working with the partners to grow share versus competitors. And that will take some learning with customers to get used to a new technology and really a whole new product than what they're used to. So I like where we stand in that race.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Gilardi of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Gilardi of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to stay on the China discussion. So you mentioned that your market share took a little step backward. And obviously, you guys have been growing share pretty rapidly over there. You kind of characterized it as more, sounds like a customer dow
componenttext: I just wanted to stay on the China discussion. So you mentioned that your market share took a little step backward. And obviously, you guys have been growing share pretty rapidly over there. You kind of characterized it as more, sounds like a customer downtime issue. But I'm just wondering, has there been a stronger competitive response from [indiscernible] or any of your local competitors there given how quickly you had taken share in that market? And is that part of the reason why the share stepped back a little bit?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Ross. Now, in fact, that's what I want to highlight in my comments that our penetration at our customers, which also by other engines, has grown. So to the contrary, we continue to make inroads with -- for exactly the reasons that
componenttext: Thanks for the question, Ross. Now, in fact, that's what I want to highlight in my comments that our penetration at our customers, which also by other engines, has grown. So to the contrary, we continue to make inroads with -- for exactly the reasons that Rich mentioned. The engines are doing well, the advantage of our customers. What happened is our truck customers basically didn't discount as much and didn't participate in the market as much in the first quarter. There was quite a bit of activity in the market and quite a bit of discounting by a couple of folks. But just more activity. They didn't participate in that same sort of thing and so they step back in their truck share. We're not the least bit worried about that. We think that works itself out over the course of the year. So we feel very good about our market share projection. In fact, our penetration is ahead of where we hope it would be so we feel really good about that. So very good position, very strong. The real question really is going to be how will the market do? Market does well, we'll see that pick up. It's a better position we've ever been and so that we'll just wait for the market to pick back up.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Thank you. And I think you mentioned 25% to 30% growth in China components, if I got that correct? And is that shown up in your Components segment? Or your JV income? And assuming it's in the segment, is that a major reason why you were sort of ab
componenttext: Got it. Thank you. And I think you mentioned 25% to 30% growth in China components, if I got that correct? And is that shown up in your Components segment? Or your JV income? And assuming it's in the segment, is that a major reason why you were sort of able to hold like a 14% margin in Components and if that tailed off would you have to give some of that back, do you think over the course of the year? And I'm talking the way you are currently reporting it as obviously to the restatement you are going to make.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Components will not be affected by the restatement, by the restructuring. Just to be clear. But the point about Components that the China business that you talked about, 27% increase. And that was a result of -- again, as Rich were saying, they are enf
componenttext: So Components will not be affected by the restatement, by the restructuring. Just to be clear. But the point about Components that the China business that you talked about, 27% increase. And that was a result of -- again, as Rich were saying, they are enforcing their standards. And so we're having much more equipment go on, Chinese engines, both aftertreatment, the mainline but also fuel systems going into this [indiscernible] because electricity fuel systems are now pretty much required in order to meet the standard. So what we're seeing is more content on our customers engines. And our own engines in order to meet these new standards. This is what's really driving that. They do -- it's a good business. It does contribute to our business. But it's not higher mix in terms of margin or anything else. So I would say our 14% margin is good all the way around.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the reason why margin stood out as long [indiscernible] Components even though North American markets were down quite significantly, it's getting back to that material cost focus. You're seeing terrific improvement in material costs in the Components
componenttext: Yes, the reason why margin stood out as long [indiscernible] Components even though North American markets were down quite significantly, it's getting back to that material cost focus. You're seeing terrific improvement in material costs in the Components segment which enabled them to offset the volume and offset fairly significant foreign currency impact. We still stayed at 14%.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso with Evercore.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious 6 months now since the analyst meeting and obviously, the tone there was very positive about looking for deals. I was just curious if you can give us an update 6 months later, are we closer, further away? And what are some of the impediments
componenttext: I was curious 6 months now since the analyst meeting and obviously, the tone there was very positive about looking for deals. I was just curious if you can give us an update 6 months later, are we closer, further away? And what are some of the impediments to getting the deals done?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, thanks for the question. So we are, we remain actively engaged in that process, as I mentioned that the investor conference, I've got a group of people that I'm working with directly on that. So I'm very engaged in it personally. And we are
componenttext: Thanks, David, thanks for the question. So we are, we remain actively engaged in that process, as I mentioned that the investor conference, I've got a group of people that I'm working with directly on that. So I'm very engaged in it personally. And we are dutifully looking along the tracks that we are talking about there where we think we can leverage our capabilities to grow. We're also of course remaining disciplined in terms of what we think is value additive to the shareholders in terms of how we do it. Unfortunate thing about things like this is there's nothing to report until there is something to report. And anything in the interim will be -- just biased our own process. So unfortunately, I can only say that we are remaining active. I'm very optimistic that we're looking at the right places and thinking about the right things and that whatever we do, if we -- when we do something, it will be beneficial to our shareholders and beneficial to the company [indiscernible]. That part I'm sure. I'm sorry that I can't provide you more details and this is because anything I'd say will just not help us in anyway and help our shareholders. But I will just tell you that nothing has changed about our process. We're still very active in the still feel good about what we're looking at.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess maybe a way to answer it a little bit, are you 6 months later, a lot further down the road on narrowing and focusing on what you logically can target and what think a deal could occur? Or is it still as wide as it was 6 months ago?
componenttext: I guess maybe a way to answer it a little bit, are you 6 months later, a lot further down the road on narrowing and focusing on what you logically can target and what think a deal could occur? Or is it still as wide as it was 6 months ago?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have done a lot of work to focus and figure out what's most important to us, a lot of work on that. [indiscernible]
componenttext: We have done a lot of work to focus and figure out what's most important to us, a lot of work on that. [indiscernible]

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just talk stock about how you expect to manage higher input cost in the second half of the year given higher commodity prices? And what's your latest thinking on pricing impact overall for the year?
componenttext: Just talk stock about how you expect to manage higher input cost in the second half of the year given higher commodity prices? And what's your latest thinking on pricing impact overall for the year?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So pricing impact for overall for the year is pretty much in line with what we said, 3 months ago. It's somewhere around 4 -- 0.4%, 0.5% negative impact on margin. So no, we've seen that in Q1. we are clearly working that though real cost improvement and
componenttext: So pricing impact for overall for the year is pretty much in line with what we said, 3 months ago. It's somewhere around 4 -- 0.4%, 0.5% negative impact on margin. So no, we've seen that in Q1. we are clearly working that though real cost improvement and no change, no update in that as we look forward now through the rest of the year. And the first part of the question was?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Commodity prices have increased.
componenttext: Commodity prices have increased.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: How do you expect to manage that in the second half?
componenttext: How do you expect to manage that in the second half?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at it, it will been a minimal impact on that. So we see some of that and we also have agreement with both customers and suppliers. We do some hedging in that area. So at least at the level that we're projecting commodity price increa
componenttext: I think when you look at it, it will been a minimal impact on that. So we see some of that and we also have agreement with both customers and suppliers. We do some hedging in that area. So at least at the level that we're projecting commodity price increases in the second half of the year that it will be minimal impact on our EBIT.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good thing for us is we're kind of operationally hedged, in the sense that as commodity price increase, of course, so does demand for mining products. So again, if there are short-term differences, where things move a little bit and mining doesn't pick up
componenttext: Good thing for us is we're kind of operationally hedged, in the sense that as commodity price increase, of course, so does demand for mining products. So again, if there are short-term differences, where things move a little bit and mining doesn't pick up. But in cost do. But generally speaking, when commodity prices rise in a significant amount, that's hard for us to offset in our cost structure. We also see mining business improve which more than offset it. So in a way, commodity prices improving is a good thing rather than a bad thing for us.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then outside of M&A, that David was asking about, to what extent has the weakness in the heavy duty truck market caused you to accelerate any of your other strategic plans, product oriented that you talked about at your Investor Day? I thought y
componenttext: Okay. And then outside of M&A, that David was asking about, to what extent has the weakness in the heavy duty truck market caused you to accelerate any of your other strategic plans, product oriented that you talked about at your Investor Day? I thought you said in your Investor Day that 10 and 12 liter was in 2018 and I think on this call, you said 2017 so are you accelerating some of those, maybe more product strategies?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Let me clear on that. Actual bring product here in 2017 late in the year which is what we intended to say that the investor conference. really go to production in 2018.
componenttext: No. Let me clear on that. Actual bring product here in 2017 late in the year which is what we intended to say that the investor conference. really go to production in 2018.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the strategy work that David asked about, our -- we are accelerating now, we're accelerating then. That we're really -- we have really focused on the efforts that are important to us strategically. So there's not a change. But we are worki
componenttext: And in terms of the strategy work that David asked about, our -- we are accelerating now, we're accelerating then. That we're really -- we have really focused on the efforts that are important to us strategically. So there's not a change. But we are working pretty quickly to figure out what's most important for us to do and figure out how to do it. No change.

componenttext: The question on distribution first off. Just in light of the updated currency assumptions which obviously hits that segment, especially hard in both ways. How should we think about the update there? And as well as the distributor acquisition? And I know at this point there's probably only small ones left. But may be any color on those two items in terms of how it potentially impacts the balance of the year?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on foreign currency, I'll answer really for the company and then we can dive into distribution deeper if you want. In the first quarter, we had a 3% negative impact from sales and then a $19 million impact on profitability negative for the company
componenttext: I think on foreign currency, I'll answer really for the company and then we can dive into distribution deeper if you want. In the first quarter, we had a 3% negative impact from sales and then a $19 million impact on profitability negative for the company. Given where currency rates currently are today, we expect foreign currency headwind on the company for the rest of the year to be much less than what we've seen for the past 1.5 years. We have now guided for the full year in currency to be down about $200 million in sales so 1 percentage point. And fairly neutral actually on profitability for the full year. So if we just back into the rest of the year, that would imply that the sales impact is going to be less than 1% negative as opposed to 3% in the first quarter and profitability should be a little bit better across all of the segments than what we've seen in Q1 and for most of last year. And obviously, distribution, we have the [indiscernible] the segment has been more exposed to currency movements. So that should help as it moves to quarter 2.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this and always balance out. You probably know that [indiscernible]. Distribution operates in every currency. Still, we can have currencies which are strengthening or weakening relative to the U.S. dollar. But on balance, they can work their way out be
componenttext: At this and always balance out. You probably know that [indiscernible]. Distribution operates in every currency. Still, we can have currencies which are strengthening or weakening relative to the U.S. dollar. But on balance, they can work their way out because some might be going the other way. But so I think distributions still has currency exposure. But hopefully, as Pat said, on balance, we'll see a little bit less of a negative impact. The one thing I would just highlight to you is we did see improvement in margin this quarter and that's despite currency and other challenges there. So that's a pretty good evidence that some of the synergies and other things that what they've been doing is starting to pay off to the question earlier. I think with the distributor acquisition, you're right. There's just the 1 month in North America left to do. That's the 1 we'll finish this year. That's in California. So it's not that small distributor actually. It's not the biggest. But it's decent in size. But we'll be acquiring that in the second half of the year and when that's complete, we will now then own all of the North American distributors and the process will be complete for North America. And as Rich highlighted earlier, we'll be than kind of full in to begin on how we capture the synergies that we know are available to us.

And then we'll refresh every segment guidance with the new reporting structure next quarter.

componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about the heavy-duty truck revenue? You talked about some of the challenges in the OE volumes into North America. But the overall kind of revenue there, better than what we're seeing in North America, no equipment trends. So what you're seeing in the parts side, whether owned in distribution, is improving some of the demand there as you manage that process? But some of the offsets to North America in heavy-duty truck volumes within the reported revenues for segment volumes?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The price revenues have remained pretty steady and actually continue to grow slightly through this, in the heavy-duty side. The distribution piece is more indirect on the part sales. So we think by our regional distribution strategy, increasing availabili
componenttext: The price revenues have remained pretty steady and actually continue to grow slightly through this, in the heavy-duty side. The distribution piece is more indirect on the part sales. So we think by our regional distribution strategy, increasing availability, et cetera, we'll get some upside there. But it's more around the synergies of getting product out there on parts. So I don't -- I wouldn't attribute the acquisition to increasing part sales although not we participate in those revenue didn't use to we didn't joint venture at the same level. The other thing that's, I'm just going to mention indirectly to your question, it relates a little bit on the Components and heavy-duty space, our strategy is to -- we sell engines to people who are vertically integrated. And so -- and we sell engines. But when we don't sell engines, we sell components. So some of the movement between engines and components, the components business continues to benefit from that. And our share in things like turbos are over 60% and that's remain solid. Our share in aftertreatment are over 50%. And so we've continued to maintain that in a time regardless of what's happening on market share on the engine side.

So a modest our outlook for the overall heavy-duty as asking that question.
