headline: Cummins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about the first half of the year decremental. I think if you exclude the contingency charge that was about 19%. And looking at kind of what's implied for the back half of the year, it looks like that steps up to more like your long-term target
componenttext: You talked about the first half of the year decremental. I think if you exclude the contingency charge that was about 19%. And looking at kind of what's implied for the back half of the year, it looks like that steps up to more like your long-term target around 25%, 26%. Could you just talk about some of the drivers of that shift from first half to second half. And then, the volume impact, any mix considerations or other items you're looking at for the steeper decremental in the back half?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start with [indiscernible]. I think, as we're looking into the second half of the year, we are going to see continued pressure in the top line. If we look at the implied sales for the second half of the year, they are going to be lower than the
componenttext: Yes, I'll start with [indiscernible]. I think, as we're looking into the second half of the year, we are going to see continued pressure in the top line. If we look at the implied sales for the second half of the year, they are going to be lower than the first half of the year. They're going to be lower in some of those areas where we do have pretty good margins today. In addition to that, we're going to see -- continue to see material cost savings but not at the rate that we've been booking through the first half of the year. They will come down in the second half of the year. And the third element I would throw in there too, we increased people's salaries in the middle of the year. So there's a merit cost increase component of this, which is also going to play, to some extent, not a huge extent, on the decremental margins in the second half compared to the first half. I'm very pleased with what we've done in the first half of the year at 23%, even with the one-offs that we've talked about, and I'm feeling pretty confident we can at least deliver the 25% that we've committed to at the start of the year.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you kept the guidance for the market share in North America Class 8 range of 27% to 30%. The year-over-year decline that we've seen is primarily driven by lower volumes with Daimler, which you talked about a little bit last quarter. But ju
componenttext: Okay. And then, you kept the guidance for the market share in North America Class 8 range of 27% to 30%. The year-over-year decline that we've seen is primarily driven by lower volumes with Daimler, which you talked about a little bit last quarter. But just as we think about navigating through some of the underproduction right now in North America Class 8, you move into next year and maybe things get aligned with in-market demand, do you think that the most likely scenario is that 2016 is a low point? And do you anticipate that your share moves up after we move beyond some of the underproduction considerations this year?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rich. I think, what you've seen over this year is a lot of movement in our share with OEs as the volumes change and that drove some different activities. As you'll notice the recent months, that's pretty much settled out now, where our share is wi
componenttext: This is Rich. I think, what you've seen over this year is a lot of movement in our share with OEs as the volumes change and that drove some different activities. As you'll notice the recent months, that's pretty much settled out now, where our share is with each customer, and so our approach now is how do we help the customers that are using our engines gain share, and so we're actually quite excited about the changes we've got in 2017 with the improved fuel economy again that you're going to see. We're going to have the best service intervals in the industry and the best connectivity, and so we're going to help those customers grow. And so I think we do view this as kind of the settling point. And then, also just remind you, the end of next year, in small numbers, we'll begin introducing our X12 product, okay? So our 12-liter product, kind of aimed at the low end, the medium bore market, where we haven't really had an offering there. So again, I think we're pretty settled out for where we are now, and kind of start the slow slog of improving share from this point.

componenttext: Just wanted to ask you about your outlook for your medium-duty market share. I know you said 74% this year, but just I wanted to see if you had any thoughts longer term considering Daimler are introducing DD5 and DD8, and considering what Ford is doing?

componenttext: So again, we won't give our guidance for 2017 on that, but for this year, we'll stay in the same range, and we'll see potentially some small reductions in 2017 as Daimler will introduce the MDEG engine late this year, and we'll be seeing that into 2017. So there's a little negative pressure there. There also is -- we intend to grow our share at Navistar, and so those 2 will be competing with each other, and then we'll -- at some point, we'll give guidance what the net of all that is, but don't look for big changes in share through the next -- through 2017.

componenttext: I think, we're just running a little bit behind flat for the first half of the year. So I think we'll -- the guidance has come up, and so we'll stay close to flat. There's some moving pieces in some of the smaller JVs that don't get the headlines, there's just really noise around the numbers.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I think, in India -- Tim, in India, we are seeing good progress in the truck market, and that's benefiting our joint venture straight through. The challenge we've had is the Indian rupee just keeps falling against the dollar, so every incremental doll
componenttext: But I think, in India -- Tim, in India, we are seeing good progress in the truck market, and that's benefiting our joint venture straight through. The challenge we've had is the Indian rupee just keeps falling against the dollar, so every incremental dollar we make, we give X percent back in currency losses, but still, I mean, the joint venture is benefiting from a stronger market. That's straightforward. In China, because we have this situation where we're not -- we're keeping good share, we're doing well with our customers, but our customer, Dongfeng, is not holding share in the market relative to another competitor. That's kind of offsetting some of our -- the benefit of the market, and that's what we're highlighting there. So that's -- as Mark said, that's just some of the dynamics in the market. We'd of course love our customer, Dongfeng, to win, and our intent is to help find ways to help them win. But right now, that's what happened in the first half. It just kind of offset part of what we saw with the strong market in China. We don't think that's a long-term trend. We think that'll come back over time, but it's just in the first half, and we just don't know what's going to happen in the second half.

componenttext: The one I'd add to that, it's not as significant as the ones that Rich just talked about, but if you go back and look at the 8-K that we filed last week, we did explain that in 2016, we've taken another look at how we're allocating some of the corporate costs across the 4 business segments, and we've kind of lowered some of the cost that are being allocated to the Engine segment and recognized the Distribution and Components are now going to incur more corporate support, and as a result, more corporate overhead, too. headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Cummins Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr.
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Cummins Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Mark Smith, Vice President of Financial Relations. Mr. Smith, you may begin.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our teleconference today to discuss Cummins' results for the third quarter of 2016.Participating with me today are our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Linebarger; our Chief Financial Officer, Pa
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our teleconference today to discuss Cummins' results for the third quarter of 2016.
Participating with me today are our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Linebarger; our Chief Financial Officer, Pat Ward; and President and Chief Operating Officer, Rich Freeland. We'll all be available for your questions after our prepared remarks.
Before we start, please note that some of the information that you will hear or be given today will consist of forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934.
Such statements express our forecasts, expectations, hopes, beliefs and intentions on strategies regarding the future.
Our actual future results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements because of a number of risks and uncertainties.
More information regarding such risks and uncertainties is available in the forward-looking disclosure statement in our slide deck today and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, particularly the Risk Factors section of our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K and our subsequently filed quarterly reports on Form 10-Q.
During the course of this call, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures, and we'll refer you to our website for the reconciliation of those measures to GAAP financial metrics.
Our press release, with a copy of the financial statements and of today's webcast presentation, are available on our website at cummins.com under the heading of Investors and Media. 
Now I'll turn it over to our Chairman and CEO, Tom Linebarger.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning. I will start with a summary of our third quarter results and provide an update on our outlook for the full year. Pat will then take you through more details of both our third quarter financial performance and our forecast fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. Good morning. I will start with a summary of our third quarter results and provide an update on our outlook for the full year. Pat will then take you through more details of both our third quarter financial performance and our forecast for the year.
Revenues for the third quarter were $4.2 billion, a decrease of 9% compared to the third quarter of 2015. Third quarter EBIT was $398 million or 9.5% of sales compared to $577 million or 12.5% in the same quarter last year. 
Our results this quarter include a $99 million increase in accrual for a loss contingency. As we have disclosed in prior quarters, the loss contingency relates to the cost of the campaign to remedy quality issues with aftertreatment systems sourced by one of our OEM customers from a third party and paired with our engines in the OEM vehicles. The combination of the Cummins engine with a third-party aftertreatment system is unique to this particular OEM.
We increased our accrual in the third quarter to reflect recent testing results that indicate that similar quality issues are impacting a second population of vehicles manufactured by the same OEM. We have accrued the expected cost of the campaign, but final resolution of cost sharing with our OEM customer has not been finalized. All parties are committed to supporting the vehicle owners, and the agreed plant to replace the aftertreatment system is currently being executed. 
Excluding the loss contingency, we delivered decremental EBIT margins of 23% in the third quarter, better than our target of 25%, reflecting strong operational performance in the face of very weak markets. Benefits from the restructuring actions we initiated in the fourth quarter of 2015, strong execution of material initiatives and productivity gains all helped to mitigate the impact of lower volumes in the third quarter.
Engine business revenues decreased by 12% year-over-year, primarily due to the lower industry production of heavy- and medium-duty trucks in North America. Earnings before interest and tax was 4.8% of sales, down from 10.3% a year ago. Excluding the loss contingency, EBIT was 10.1% compared to 10.3% a year ago. 
Restructuring benefits, material cost reduction and lower warranty costs all contributed to the strong operating results. 
Revenues in our Components segment decreased 8% from a year ago, with lower demand in North America more than offsetting growth in China. Sales in China increased by 37% as demand for our products continues to outpace end market growth. Despite the lower sales, EBIT percent improved from 12.6% to 12.9% as strong execution of our cost-reduction programs more than offset the impact of weaker volumes.
Distribution revenues decreased 3% compared to the third quarter of 2015. The positive impact of acquisitions made in the second half of 2015 were more than offset by the negative impact of currency and weaker sales to the off-highway market. The Distribution business' EBIT for the quarter was 6.4%, down from 7.9% a year ago as results last year benefiting from gains on the acquisition of 3 distributor joint ventures. The positive impact of operational improvement and increased pricing were offset by a negative impact of currency.
Revenues for the Power Systems business declined by 13% year-over-year, with lower sales in most regions due to weaker demand in Power Generation, commercial marine and oil and gas markets. EBIT declined from 7.5% to 6.9%, with decremental EBIT margin just 12%, due in part to a 15% reduction in operating expenses in the business.
Now I'll comment on some of our key markets, starting with North America. Our revenues in North America declined by 13% in the third quarter due to weaker demand in on-highway market especially heavy-duty trucks. We shipped 16,400 engines to the North America heavy-duty market in the third quarter, a decrease of 33% from a year ago. Our market share improved from the second quarter of this year and stands at 31% year-to-date. We are forecasting full year industry production to be 200,000 units and our market share to be in the range of 27% to 30%, unchanged from our projections 3 months ago.
Frost and Sullivan recognized Cummins as a leading supplier of heavy-duty engines to the U.S. heavy-duty truck market, reflecting the results of its extensive survey of both truck fleets and owner operators.
In the medium-duty truck market, we delivered approximately 18,000 engines in the third quarter, down 20% from last year. Our market share through the end of August was 73%, within the range of our full-year guidance of between 72% to 75%. Industry production dipped sharply in the third quarter and is not expected to improve in the fourth quarter. And as a result, we have lowered our full year forecast of market size to 108,000 units from 117,000 units 3 months ago.
Our engine shipments to North American pickup truck customers increased by 2% in the third quarter. Shipments to Chrysler declined by 11% due to planned production changes at Chrysler plants but was more than offset by shipments of our V8 engine to Nissan, which we launched in the fourth quarter of last year. We currently expect our revenues in the pickup segment to increase by 10% in 2016, down a little from our prior forecast of 12% growth.
Our Engine revenues in North America construction market decreased by 21% compared to the third quarter of last year. While housing and commercial construction activity remains positive, weaker demand in the oil and gas market has led to an excess supply of used equipment. 
Power Systems revenues declined 8% in North America in the third quarter due to primarily to lower engine orders from oil and gas and mining customers.
Our international revenues declined by 3% year-over-year, driven by lower sales in the Middle East and Africa, which more than offset growth in China. Weak commodity prices and slowing economic activity negatively impact the demand for Power Generation equipment in the Middle East and Africa.
Third quarter revenues in China, including joint ventures, were $826 million, an increase of 6% due to growth in on-highway and construction revenues. Industry demand for heavy- and medium-duty trucks in China increased by 30% in the third quarter.
Our market share in the third quarter was 16.5%, up from the second quarter but down from 17.9% a year ago.
Some OEMs have been aggressively discounting trucks this year to gain share in the near term while our partner, Dongfeng, has experienced decline in market share. We expect our full year Engine market share to be 16% compared to 16.4% in 2015.
We now project full year industry sales to increase 16% to 870,000 units this year, up from our prior forecast of 820,000 units or 9% growth.
Shipment of our light-duty engines from China grew 23% in the third quarter compared to a 3% increase for the overall market as we increased penetration at Foton, displacing local competitor engine. Our share of the overall market was up -- was 7.7%, up 120 basis points year-over-year. We currently project industry sales to decline by 4% for the year, unchanged from 3 months ago. Industry sales of excavators in China decreased -- increased, excuse me, by 43% in the third quarter, and our volumes more than doubled off a very small base due to stronger investment in real estate, driving uptick in equipment demand. While this was a nice increase, construction equipment market in China are still very weak in historical terms.
Revenues for our Power Systems business in China declined by 11% in the third quarter, reflecting weak demand in Marine, mining and power generation markets. Full year revenues in China across all segments, including joint ventures, are expected to grow 4% for the year, up from our prior forecast of 3% due to stronger demand in the heavy- and medium-duty truck market. Third quarter revenues in India, including joint ventures, were $376 million and flat year-over-year, with lower on-highway volumes offsetting growth in Power Generation construction and aftermarket revenues. Industry truck production dropped by 17% compared to a year ago, after a very strong first half of the year.
Truck OEMs lowered build rates reduce inventories as sales slowed in the third quarter. For the full year, we now forecast industry truck production to be 340,000 units, up 6% year-over-year but down from our prior forecast of 370,000 units. We currently project our market share to be 41%, up from 40% in 2015.
We currently project full year revenues across all segments in India and including joint ventures to increase 5%, consistent with our prior forecast. Strong demand in construction and improving demand in Power Generation are expected to offset the weaker outlook for trucks.
Third quarter revenues in Brazil were $85 million, up 9% from the third quarter last year, reflecting a modest improvement in sales to on-highway markets. Our shipments of engines to truck customers increased 5% while overall industry truck production declined by 14% [ph] year-over-year. We project full year industry truck production to decline by 20%, unchanged from 3 months ago.
Our sales in the Middle East declined by 12% in the third quarter, primarily impacting our Power Systems business and reflecting weakness in infrastructure investment in the region.
As a result of the slowed pace of growth in the global economy, we continue to face persistently weak demand in a number of our largest markets. Our restructuring and other cost-reduction initiatives are helping to maintain EBIT margins well above trough levels from 3 [ph] prior cycles. In addition to reducing cost and improving productivity, we've also continued to invest in our business to improve our competitive position throughout this protracted downturn. 
In the fourth quarter, we will acquire our last remaining distributor joint venture in North America, completing the strategic initiative that we announced in 2013 and allowing us to improve the consistency and quality of our service and support to our customers wherever they operate.
We've also continued to invest in new products. For example, we're growing sales and market share with our new QSK95 engine even in extremely challenging markets. We currently expect our full year sales to decline by 9%, consistent with our prior guidance. EBIT percent is now expected to be 11.3%, down from our prior guidance of 11.6% to 12.2%, largely as a result of the increased accrual from the loss contingency in the Engine business. Our EBIT expectation for the Components, Distribution and Power System businesses are all unchanged from 3 months ago. We remain on track to deliver our goal of 25% decremental EBIT margin for the whole year of 2016.
So far this year, we have returned $1.3 billion to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases, consistent with our plan to return 75% of operating cash flow to shareholders. 
Thank you for your interest today, and now turn it over to Pat, who will cover third quarter results and full year guidance in more detail.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Third quarter revenues were $4.2 billion, a decrease of 9% from a year ago.Sales in North America, which represented 59% of our third quarter revenues, declined 13% from last year due primarily to lower demand
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Third quarter revenues were $4.2 billion, a decrease of 9% from a year ago.
Sales in North America, which represented 59% of our third quarter revenues, declined 13% from last year due primarily to lower demand in heavy- and medium-duty truck markets and declines in power generation and industrial engine sales.
International sales declined by 3% from a year ago as increased sales in China helped to offset weaker demand in both the Middle East and in Africa.
Despite the 9% decline in revenues, gross margins of 25.8% of sales were only down 30 basis points from last year with material cost savings, productivity improvements and the benefits of the restructuring actions helping offset the negative impact from lower volumes and an unfavorable product mix.
Selling, admin and research and development costs of $670 million or 16% of sales decreased by $57 million year-over-year, mainly due to restructuring actions executed in the fourth quarter of 2015 and lower spending for research and development projects but did increase as a percent of sales by 30 [ph] basis points.
Joint venture income of $74 million decreased $4 million compared to a year ago, primarily due to lower earnings in Power Systems, joint ventures and the acquisition of North American distributors previously held as unconsolidated joint ventures.
Earnings before interest and tax were $398 million or 9.5% of sales for the quarter compared to 12.5% a year ago. Included in the quarter was an additional $99 million charge related to the previously disclosed loss contingency, as Tom just discussed. Excluding this charge, our decremental EBIT margin was 23% compared to the same quarter last year, slightly better than the 25% that we previously committed to.
We are benefiting from a lower cost structure due to the actions taken take in fourth quarter of 2015 and strong execution on the cost-reduction programs and productivity improvements. Net earnings for the quarter were $289 million or $1.72 per diluted share with the increased accrual from the loss contingency net of compensation reducing diluted earnings per share by $0.30.
Net income in the third quarter of 2015 was $380 million or $2.14 per diluted share. Effective tax rate for the quarter was 21.5%, lower than a year ago primarily due to changes in the geographical mix of pretax income. I will now highlight the performance of the individual operating segments during the third quarter and provide updated guidance for the full year.
In the Engine segment, revenues were $1.9 billion, a decrease of 12% from last year. On-highway revenues declined 13% [ph] due to lower levels of heavy- and medium-duty truck production in North America. Off-highway revenues declined 6% due to continued weak global demand. Segment EBIT was $89 million or 4.8% of sales, which included the $99 million charge to increase our estimate for the loss contingency previously disclosed. Excluding this additional provision, the Engine segment EBIT was 10.1% of sales compared to 10.3% in the third quarter of last year.
Material cost savings, warranty and benefits and previous restructuring actions partially offset the negative impact of lower volumes and an unfavorable product mix.
For full year 2016, we now expect Engine segment revenues to be down 11% from 2015 levels, primarily due to weaker truck production in North America compared to our guidance 3 months ago for sales to decline between 9% and 12%. EBIT margins for 2016 are now expected to be 8.75% when taking into account the $99 million loss contingency charge [indiscernible] prior guidance of 10% to 11%.
For Distribution segment, third quarter revenues were $1.5 billion, down 3% compared to last year. The decrease was driven by a 5% decline in organic sales and a 1% unfavorable impact from a stronger U.S. dollar, which were partially offset by a 3% increase in revenue from acquisition made a year ago. The EBIT margin for the quarter was $96 million or 6.4% of sales, a decrease from 7.9% a year ago, mainly due to the fair market value gains recorded on distributor acquisition in the third quarter of 2015 and from the impact of negative foreign currency movements.
At the beginning of October, we completed the acquisition of the last remaining unconsolidated North American distributor pick, bringing the acquisition to 13, since we announced the plan in September of 2013.
We now expect full year revenue to decline 1% compared to last year as additional revenue from acquisition will help to offset weak demand for industrial engines and power generation equipment as well as the headwinds from foreign currency movements. We expect full year EBIT margins to be 6% at the midpoint of our previous guidance range.
For the Components segment, revenues were $1.1 billion, a decline of 8% from a year ago. Sales in North America declined 16% as industry production in on-highway markets decline. International sales increased 7%, with a 37% increase in sales in China more than offsetting weaker revenues in Europe.
Despite the lower sales, gross margins improved by 80 basis points as material cost reductions and benefits from restructuring more than offset the negative impact of weaker volumes. Segment EBIT was $148 million or 12.9% of sales compared to 12.6% of sales a year ago.
We expect full year revenue in 2016 to decline by 8%, and EBIT to be 13.25%, consistent with the midpoint of our previous guidance. 
In the Power System segment, third quarter revenues were $856 million, down 13% from a year ago. Power Generation equipment sales declined 12% due to lower demand especially in the Middle East and in Asia. Sales to industrial high-horsepower engine markets declined by 15% as weak demand continues in oil and gas, marine and Mining markets.
EBIT margins were 6.9% in the quarter, down from 7.5% last year, which equates to a decremental EBIT margin of 12%. Material cost reductions, lower costs following the 2015 restructuring actions and the benefits from a weaker British pound helped offset the impact from lower volumes and joint venture earnings. We now expect full year revenues for the Power System segment to decline by 14% compared to our previous guidance of down 12% to 14% and full year EBIT to be 7.5% of sales at the midpoint of our prior guidance.
We are now projecting total company revenues to be down 9% in 2016, consistent with our prior guidance of down 8% to 10% as we face a 31% decline in industry production of heavy-duty trucks in North America and very weak global demand for industrial engines and Power Generation equipment.
We expect EBIT margins to be 11.3% of sales this year, including the charges related to the loss contingency incurred during the year, representing full year decremental EBIT margins of 25%.
We now expect the full year effective tax rate to be 25.5% and to deliver earnings per share of approximately $8 per diluted share this year.
Turning to cash flow. Cash generated from operating activities in the quarter was $576 million, $14 million higher than last year. For the first 9 months of the year, operating cash flow is $1.3 billion, up from $1.1 billion for the same period in 2015. 
Working capital levels of $482 million were 11% lower than this time last year. And we anticipate operating cash flow in 2016 will be around $2 billion, similar to 2015 levels despite a 9% drop in revenues.
Capital expenditures are expected to be in the range of $550 million to $600 million in 2016, and we still plan to return 75% of operating cash flow to shareholders this year through a combination of dividends and share repurchases, having returned $1.3 billion year-to-date. And as you know, we increased the dividend by 5% during the third quarter. And year-to-date, have repurchased 7 million shares. 
Now I'll turn it back over to Mark.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Pat. And we are ready now to turn over to the Q&A section. Operator, please go ahead with that part of the call. [Operator Instructions]
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Pat. And we are ready now to turn over to the Q&A section. Operator, please go ahead with that part of the call. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the contract structure regarding the warranty cost that impacted you for the past few quarters going forward, are you still underwriting the warranty risk for the third-party aftertreatment? Are we able to get the contract structure mod
componenttext: Can you talk about the contract structure regarding the warranty cost that impacted you for the past few quarters going forward, are you still underwriting the warranty risk for the third-party aftertreatment? Are we able to get the contract structure modified on new shipments? And can you talk about in terms of the size of the population now with the additional charge, what proportion of the total population has been provisioned for?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jerry. Let me take a shot at those series of questions. So as you alluded to, it's a unique situation our engine with third-party aftertreatment. So the only one we have kind of in the company. What we did here in this quarter was we increased the a
componenttext: Okay, Jerry. Let me take a shot at those series of questions. So as you alluded to, it's a unique situation our engine with third-party aftertreatment. So the only one we have kind of in the company. What we did here in this quarter was we increased the accrual for a second population of vehicles. And so there -- as we did some additional testing, we now found that this second population is going to need to have a recall also. So that was the increase that you saw in Q3. So now we have -- the population is set. We estimated the cost of those accruals -- of those recalls, and that's what's reflected in our numbers. What we have not concluded is the commercial negotiations with the OEM customer. And so while we don't expect the final outcome to be much materially higher, in fact, could be lower. As far as your ongoing kind of what was implied in there is there more to come, I guess, is maybe what you were also asking. What we have is there are 3 populations, and we have accrued for 2 of those. The third population we have not accrued for, and it's a different cycle that's involved in this third population. It has a different emission standard that's, in fact, higher than this. And third, we have concluded our emissions test, and all emission tests to date have passed. And so that third population is similar in size to the other 2 that we have taken an accrual on. And of course, we're adjusting all the agreements going forward so for the ongoing issue. And I guess lastly, and implied but the fix has been put in place for sometime. So the production -- the products being shipped today do not have these issues. We're talking about a fixed amount that, unfortunately, we had to come back to a couple of times. I guess one last thing, just to maybe close this out is -- in fact, the product that we're talking about is doing terrific. And we're actually gaining sales, gaining share. Out at the plant, the producers of engine yesterday we're in process of taking up production at the end of the year to meet increased demand. So it's an unfortunate situation, it's disappointing, it's complex, it's unique, but at this point, we've accrued for kind of all the known issues and that will kind of move in the commercial negotiations to try to finish that one up to come.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate the context. And the second question, on the engine, obviously end markets have been tough, but can you talk about how the production plan is been tracking versus your initial product expectations as we head into '17? And if you're will
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate the context. And the second question, on the engine, obviously end markets have been tough, but can you talk about how the production plan is been tracking versus your initial product expectations as we head into '17? And if you're willing to quantify the top line contribution that will be significant enough to call out as we think about '17 versus '16?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jerry. This is Rich again. A little bit ahead of our projection on the hedgehog despite the weak markets. And so driven primarily due to the data center markets where this is proven to be a terrific product to meet those margins. We're also have g
componenttext: Thanks, Jerry. This is Rich again. A little bit ahead of our projection on the hedgehog despite the weak markets. And so driven primarily due to the data center markets where this is proven to be a terrific product to meet those margins. We're also have gone into production in marine applications and rail applications. So we started the year building I think 3 a week. We're up to, we're right now at 5 a week as we go into the year. And so we had -- I don't have a projection for 2017, but I'll just close and say we're really pleased with how this is gotten -- how we got a good start here despite these bad markets coming out ahead of plan. And a total top line revenue kind of in the $150 million to $180 million range this year.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Potter with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Potter with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask, I guess, a couple of questions on China. First, it looks like the deadlines for compliance with the new NS5 and NS6 emission standards have been announced. So just hoping you could give an update regarding the incremental content you expe
componenttext: I wanted to ask, I guess, a couple of questions on China. First, it looks like the deadlines for compliance with the new NS5 and NS6 emission standards have been announced. So just hoping you could give an update regarding the incremental content you expect to be capturing at each step along the way as emission standard gets more complex. And then as well your expectations for timing and severity of any prebuy we might end up seeing?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Take a first shot at the this. So for the NS5, Jerry, not a lot of -- oh, sorry, Alex. The NS5 not a lot of content increase. And therefore, not a lot of price increase, and we don't anticipate a prebuy on the NS5. So big step up for the content into gett
componenttext: Take a first shot at the this. So for the NS5, Jerry, not a lot of -- oh, sorry, Alex. The NS5 not a lot of content increase. And therefore, not a lot of price increase, and we don't anticipate a prebuy on the NS5. So big step up for the content into getting into those issues will be more in the NS6 range. And then given the experience on NS4, we're more optimistic about enforcement and implementation of both NS5 and NS6.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in terms of the timing of the prebuy associated with NS6, that would be probably something, what, 2019?
componenttext: Okay. And in terms of the timing of the prebuy associated with NS6, that would be probably something, what, 2019?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, the last one on China and then I'll turn it over, is status update regarding the revolutionary engine coming out of China, coming to the U.S. I guess any sort of progress update you could give there? Any progress you've made negot
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, the last one on China and then I'll turn it over, is status update regarding the revolutionary engine coming out of China, coming to the U.S. I guess any sort of progress update you could give there? Any progress you've made negotiating with OEMs in the U.S. as well as on the production side, status of that?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks for remembering the revolutionary engine. We're on track. We're going to bring that in late 2017. We have multiple OEMs signed up to use that product. It's going to be a terrific product -- where weight is important, so in the day cab
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks for remembering the revolutionary engine. We're on track. We're going to bring that in late 2017. We have multiple OEMs signed up to use that product. It's going to be a terrific product -- where weight is important, so in the day cab area, in vocational markets and those that have followed Cummins for a long time think back to our M11 [ph] product was a real success there. So we're on track. We're moving ahead with that.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, I'm just trying to think about sort of broadly 2017 -- and I know you don't want to give end market guidance, but can you talk to me about what levers you think you can pull in '17, assuming the markets are improving, whether it's rest
componenttext: Two questions. One, I'm just trying to think about sort of broadly 2017 -- and I know you don't want to give end market guidance, but can you talk to me about what levers you think you can pull in '17, assuming the markets are improving, whether it's restructuring, whether it's market share? And then capital allocation, whether it be share repo, where we are in the M&A front? And then my follow-up question, just I think you said the charge in the quarter was offset by compensation. Did you lower your compensation assumptions for the year? I just wanted to clarify that as well.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just get the first one first, Jamie. It's Tom. We did lower our compensation estimate. They are related to -- they relate to our performance targets for the year. So when performance targets estimate change then we adjust our estimate up or down ac
componenttext: Let me just get the first one first, Jamie. It's Tom. We did lower our compensation estimate. They are related to -- they relate to our performance targets for the year. So when performance targets estimate change then we adjust our estimate up or down accordingly. So we did adjust compensation estimates.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you quantify? I'm just trying to figure out how much that was or what the EPS impact is for that --
componenttext: And can you quantify? I'm just trying to figure out how much that was or what the EPS impact is for that --

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: It's about $20 million in the quarter, I think.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: $0.07, Jamie.
componenttext: $0.07, Jamie.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: About $0.07. So let's get to the 2017. As you said, we won't be giving guidance. Let me just tell you how we're thinking about it though and again, Rich can add if he had some more thoughts on it. But we are going to go into the 2017 conservative on marke
componenttext: About $0.07. So let's get to the 2017. As you said, we won't be giving guidance. Let me just tell you how we're thinking about it though and again, Rich can add if he had some more thoughts on it. But we are going to go into the 2017 conservative on markets. As we talked about before, we don't see obvious turnaround. We do see some bottoming in some markets, but there's not an obvious instigator for turnarounds. So enter 2017 much as we enter 2016, with a relatively conservative view on markets. And then trying to make sure how to get our costs appropriate -- set appropriately for those markets and how we could do to find the critical new products and new capabilities we need to succeed and grow the market. Yes, we will be targeting market share, and you probably know some of the places we're doing that, our very large engine, for example. We talked about that earlier. We're gaining share. We are expanding share in China that's both the components and engines. We have several launches there are going well. So we will be targeting to gain share in different markets where we think that opportunity exists, and we will be investing to do so. But at a high level, what you see is relatively conservative planning on market outcomes and pretty aggressive on how to get the costs in line to make sure that we keep our decremental margins at 25% or below.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any update on the M&A front, Tom? I know this is been a focus of yours, but just trying to get a sense of if there's -- if we made any progress, I guess?
componenttext: And any update on the M&A front, Tom? I know this is been a focus of yours, but just trying to get a sense of if there's -- if we made any progress, I guess?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we made tons of progress. We've done lots of good work. Again, unfortunately, the way that you'll hear about it is when we have an announcement and not in one of these calls because we can't really say anything until we say things. But yes, the thing
componenttext: Yes, we made tons of progress. We've done lots of good work. Again, unfortunately, the way that you'll hear about it is when we have an announcement and not in one of these calls because we can't really say anything until we say things. But yes, the thing I would say that's probably important for shareholders is we haven't changed our focus areas. We remain focused on areas I discussed with you. We are continued progress in those. We remain focused on how to expand our businesses here so we think we have the capabilities that will make the returns, meet our target and that we're going to invest a sum some that we think we can earn a return on. So that same conservatism about how to invest, how to make sure things we belong in, that's stayed the same as you guess it is a little bit more to find the right things but we feel optimistic. And I'll just say for myself that I'm very committed to the interest that we set out and doing it in the way that we set out in our strategy session with investors.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso with Evercore ISI.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, just following up on the idea on going into '17 now. Folks are looking at you maybe a way to play stronger emerging markets into '17, but your comment right there seems to be more on the cautious side. Can you give us a little more detail around how
componenttext: Tom, just following up on the idea on going into '17 now. Folks are looking at you maybe a way to play stronger emerging markets into '17, but your comment right there seems to be more on the cautious side. Can you give us a little more detail around how you're really thinking about the Chinese and Brazilian market and around?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, I don't mean to imply that there won't be recovery in some markets. We've seen recent recovery in the Chinese truck market this year. I just mean to say that broadly speaking, our view of the markets across Cummins markets broadly that they co
componenttext: Yes, again, I don't mean to imply that there won't be recovery in some markets. We've seen recent recovery in the Chinese truck market this year. I just mean to say that broadly speaking, our view of the markets across Cummins markets broadly that they continue to be weak. And while we may see some bottoming, we don't have an instigator for significant growth directly in front of us. So our view is given that we've been in this for a couple of years now, the right posture for the company to take is to assume relatively weak markets, set our cost structure accordingly, find opportunities for cost savings, productivity gains and then continue to invest in those opportunities where we think markets could improve and we'll be able to gain share and gain business equity. So for example in China, you've seen us have a pretty aggressive posture on new product launch and on share gain. And so if and when China starts to improve next year, if it did, we will be positioned well to take advantage of it. Of course in Brazil, we love to hear it. It's a very, very weak market. We have very strong position in Brazil. We're ready to ramp up when the market's ready. Again whether it's going to ramp up in 2017, I just don't know. So again, we're still doing work on it, Dave, so we'll have a much better view in a couple of months about -- if you see some of those markets actually starting to turn back, we'll definitely forecast those. I kind of wanted to get give you a sense of how we're approaching our planning rather than specifics on one emerging market or another.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and again I'm not trying to push you but obviously you stocks at valuation gap versus other names that was suggests. Yes, we understand some developed market weakness in truck or PowerGen, but the reason even what it is, Cummins gives me more the EM
componenttext: Okay, and again I'm not trying to push you but obviously you stocks at valuation gap versus other names that was suggests. Yes, we understand some developed market weakness in truck or PowerGen, but the reason even what it is, Cummins gives me more the EM ramp in '17, right? It's not ramp in both developed and develop markets otherwise valuation will be higher. But there is some base case of EMs should be up notably next year. Are you not yet seeing the order book or at least commentary from your customers which suggest we could think about that Brazils, the Indias, the Chinas are up double-digit for you next year? I mean, off a low basis, I appreciate it. But are you just not seeing that yet or are seeing a little bit is not willing to say?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: China we've seen improvement already this year, gave up for the China truck market. What that means for 2017, we just don't know yet. We have not seen much of an uptick in Brazil yet. Whether or not it'll be better next year, I just don't know. I just don
componenttext: China we've seen improvement already this year, gave up for the China truck market. What that means for 2017, we just don't know yet. We have not seen much of an uptick in Brazil yet. Whether or not it'll be better next year, I just don't know. I just don't -- my view is that the valuation of Cummins stock is really a good deal, really inexpensive. And so I think it be a good buy for anybody for any of those reasons. But again, my view is that we'll have a better view in February about what the individual markets are. I don't know what individual investors about assumptions for next year. But I will say that we are capacity wise, new product wise, market leadership wise, if markets go up, we will benefit more than anybody. We are positioned incredibly well for that, but we are also prepared if it doesn't turn out to do better than anybody else. And that's really as a management team all we could do is be ready for both because we just don't know whether it's our turn around and went. But as you know, our order lead time is very short. So it's very difficult to see from just an order book point of view what's going to happen in the middle of next year, but again we will have a much better view in February and I suggest we take up this conversation again.

componenttext: Okay, this is Rich again. We don't see a lot of moves in next year in the medium-duty market share. There's a couple of moving pieces that you know about, so we'll see a 4-cylinder engine being introduced at low volumes, which will be a negative. And we also though we'll see our share continue to grow at now. In fact, we introduced ISL 9-liter engine here in Q3, which is a positive. So again we'll give the further guidance, but you ought to think of kind of more of the same in '17 at this time as far as market share.

componenttext: You mentioned the ISG, which is in -- we put in heavy-duty markets. It's a but heavy-duty market, that's why -- so I just want to make sure that -- because I heard you mentioned that. That was not include in whatever Rich just talked about.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And that will come at the end of '17 [ph].

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: End of '17 [ph]. Yes, okay, that's what I was just trying to get the timing of the different pieces. And then on PowerGen, you seem to keep cutting costs, repositioning the business and the volumes keep dropping on you. Is there anything else that can be
componenttext: End of '17 [ph]. Yes, okay, that's what I was just trying to get the timing of the different pieces. And then on PowerGen, you seem to keep cutting costs, repositioning the business and the volumes keep dropping on you. Is there anything else that can be done structurally the kind of put a floor underneath those margins? And I appreciate that's kind of a terrible end market like the whole industry is struggling, but is there anything else It feels you're kind of chasing to decline a little bit. And I don't know if there's anything else to do there.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joel, it's a good comment. As you've heard me say about that in the past, I think that while we've done a really good job on reducing costs in light of our segments, I do believe over the last several years we have chased the PowerGen market down as oppos
componenttext: Joel, it's a good comment. As you've heard me say about that in the past, I think that while we've done a really good job on reducing costs in light of our segments, I do believe over the last several years we have chased the PowerGen market down as opposed to getting in front of it. And I'm disappointed in that for that reason, but I believe that we made a step early this year that is really helping us get ahead of that and find new ways to establish productivity and further reduce costs. And that was by combining our large Engine business with our gen set business. What that's brought to us is a new opportunity for both how we do production, how we consolidate production and therefore take steps out of production, whether it's supply chain, whether its inventory, which again means we end up holding less stuff, we end up holding less stuff that we don't -- we can't sell, et cetera. And then also, our new product development process, we're able to streamline that to make sure that we're ready with the products that we launch the engine producers that wanted the genset ones [ph], and we don't produce stuff that we don't need, we don't generate new products we're not going to use. So I feel like both of those -- both in terms of efficiency, cost and asset utilization, will continue to improve. We got one of our best leaders leading the group. So I think over the next year or 2, not only do I feel like we're starting to reach the bottom in some of the markets, I feel that we've got some renewed opportunities for cost reduction to further improve margins in that area. Now again, I thought that before so it's really great to talk about we got to do is deliver. No one here is confused about that.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to jump in for a second, Joel, if you keep in mind the Power Systems revenue dropped by 13% in the quarter and we managed to keep that decremental EBIT margin at 12%, I think kind of validates and I think we'll see more of that going to the fourt
componenttext: And just to jump in for a second, Joel, if you keep in mind the Power Systems revenue dropped by 13% in the quarter and we managed to keep that decremental EBIT margin at 12%, I think kind of validates and I think we'll see more of that going to the fourth quarter.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sort of similar theme and just thinking about cycles and some of your comments around markets that are bottoming. If you could just talk about kind of PowerGen broadly how you're thinking about it from a cycle of perspective and really how much more downs
componenttext: Sort of similar theme and just thinking about cycles and some of your comments around markets that are bottoming. If you could just talk about kind of PowerGen broadly how you're thinking about it from a cycle of perspective and really how much more downside is there is sort of 5 years in the declines. And similarly, just to address some of the high-horsepower key markets and whether or not there is much downside left really in say, oil, mining, some other marine markets and how confident you are in the bottom in '16 there?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. This is Rich. I'll share this one. Has it been 5 years because it feels like a decade. It does seem like we've been in the down cycle for a while, to your point and frankly, longer than we have seen in the past, which is frustrating. So obviously,
componenttext: Great. This is Rich. I'll share this one. Has it been 5 years because it feels like a decade. It does seem like we've been in the down cycle for a while, to your point and frankly, longer than we have seen in the past, which is frustrating. So obviously, we're in the discussion earlier from David, we'd like to see some of the things turn back. We just haven't seen yet signs that they're turning back. And of course, Power Generation reflects a couple of things. One, in emerging markets, it reflects infrastructure building and general economic growth, where margin start get under threat and things like that. And then it reflects non-res capital spending in some of the more mature markets where we're selling standby. And again, while nonres capital spending isn't a disaster in the U.S. and our business isn't a disaster, both those statistics across the world are [indiscernible]. So our view is where we start to see turn around PowerGen is what we start to see infrastructure spending starting to come back in some of these emerging markets across the world and then we see nonres capital spending coming back more aggressively in some of the more advanced countries. And we just -- right now, that's not just obvious when that happens. So as we were talking about, we're prepared to be at levels like we are now, a little better, little worse. And we're finding ways to get more money out of our business at those levels. We're completely ready for when it turns around to gain a lot of growth but also gain profitability improvements. So no question about that. But right now, we're approaching it conservatively. We'll see what happens, and Rich, I'll let you talk about some of the other large engine markets.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: On mining and oil and gas, no one is calling a turn around, certainly we're not, on production orders. There are -- I'd say there a couple of positives signs out there. Commodity prices up is one. But what we are seeing is some more inquiries and some mor
componenttext: On mining and oil and gas, no one is calling a turn around, certainly we're not, on production orders. There are -- I'd say there a couple of positives signs out there. Commodity prices up is one. But what we are seeing is some more inquiries and some more business both on rebuild of product and aftermarket parts, which is generally the precursor to actual orders. So it's a faint green shoot but we have seen just a little bit of that to give some optimism there. We're down 7% in mining this year, and again no one calling for that to turn around this time other than the aftermarket.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in Marine?
componenttext: And then in Marine?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marine, I would think maybe has a little longer to it. I'd probably a little more pessimistic there. Most of our marine -- a lot of marine is tied to oil and gas. So maybe 30%, 40% of our marine business is tied there. So until you see some turnaround in
componenttext: Marine, I would think maybe has a little longer to it. I'd probably a little more pessimistic there. Most of our marine -- a lot of marine is tied to oil and gas. So maybe 30%, 40% of our marine business is tied there. So until you see some turnaround in oil and gas then there'll be a lag effect there. I would say I'm more pessimistic on the Marine side.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful. And then maybe it's a little early but just thinking about a lot of the initiatives under way this year and what it means for kind of the carryover tailwind into next year and the ability to talk to what some of the productivi
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful. And then maybe it's a little early but just thinking about a lot of the initiatives under way this year and what it means for kind of the carryover tailwind into next year and the ability to talk to what some of the productivity and material and restructuring benefits mean just as a carryover benefit into next year?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, those will have a hard time seeing those because we're just putting together our plan. You can bet that our intention is to find ways to carry those over and add to those with new initiatives. That's what you've seen from us every year. You'll
componenttext: Right now, those will have a hard time seeing those because we're just putting together our plan. You can bet that our intention is to find ways to carry those over and add to those with new initiatives. That's what you've seen from us every year. You'll see that again. We'll be trying to capture the benefits of things we put in place, put in some new things to help more and then deal with whatever variations that we're seeing in the market. Again, that's kind of our broad approach to the plan. We'll be able to quantify these things much better in February.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, pretty good. And then broadly stated, could you just maybe share your thoughts on where you think the North America on-highway markets are tracking going into 2017, the medium duty forecast got cut for the second quarter in a row. And I'm wondering
componenttext: Okay, pretty good. And then broadly stated, could you just maybe share your thoughts on where you think the North America on-highway markets are tracking going into 2017, the medium duty forecast got cut for the second quarter in a row. And I'm wondering if you got any more color on what exactly you're seeing there. And then there seems to be a pretty wide range of forecast from OEMs on heavy-duty I guess. Do you think you're leaning more on the optimistic side of a flattish market or more on the pessimistic side or more declines to come?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I think we've probably been a little more pessimistic than most on this as we started the year, which is why we took a pretty big reduction in cost at the end of last year, anticipating this. There's no sign of a pickup out there right now. I think
componenttext: Okay, I think we've probably been a little more pessimistic than most on this as we started the year, which is why we took a pretty big reduction in cost at the end of last year, anticipating this. There's no sign of a pickup out there right now. I think you have a situation for many, many months we're still producing for more of the orders that are coming in, and that hasn't changed because the backlog is down to [ph] 85,000, which is kind of the forward order board. And we're hearing from lots and lots of fleets that while business is -- they're a little nervous on business, they're delaying purchases. So how do I stretch assets out a little bit? And we're in that -- that's the mode we're in right now. I don't have quite the miles that I need to make a trade out in the trucks and engines are really good out there. So you can stretch a little more out of it. And lead time was really low. So I need one, I can get it quickly. As we look at it, I see fundamental business is not bad, and so that we're maybe moving towards where retail orders are getting close to trough. I still think though from a production standpoint, there's a step down still in there, which is what we've assumed. If you run our numbers, we've said steps down in Q4 and quite frankly, I think will continue into Q1 on the production side. And so retail orders getting close to trough, production there's always a bit of lag there and we've seen -- and again that's what we've seen in other cycles, especially towards year-end. The folks that shut down at the end of the year and they start the year up. We're planning for that kind of step down in production. Now whether that actually happens or not or when it happens, what quarter, but that's how we're thinking about it kind of right now.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of product questions if I may. Your class A single cylinder for your engines and for an OEM customers, but it seems like weight savings and it seems beneficial in that way. Is there any headwind to revenue or dollar margin in components bec
componenttext: I had a couple of product questions if I may. Your class A single cylinder for your engines and for an OEM customers, but it seems like weight savings and it seems beneficial in that way. Is there any headwind to revenue or dollar margin in components because you're becoming more efficient in how you provide aftertreatment solutions to customers?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, you're accurate -- it's one of the big advantages or one of the couple advantages of the new single module, which is the weight savings on it. I can't quote the exact number but over 100 pounds that will be taken out. And then second, what we're do
componenttext: First, you're accurate -- it's one of the big advantages or one of the couple advantages of the new single module, which is the weight savings on it. I can't quote the exact number but over 100 pounds that will be taken out. And then second, what we're doing is changing the cycle to do repair on it. So we take it out well beyond the first owner so that you never have to touch the aftertreatment if you buy. So those are the big advantages. Our normal approach is we sign up with customers is to continually take costs out of product and pass that caused -- pass on those savings to customers. And aftertreatment is in the same mode that we pass those material cost savings after taking costs out and working with customers, share that with them.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that big enough to impact the growth curve on components or not?
componenttext: Is that big enough to impact the growth curve on components or not?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really depends I think on -- this is Tom speaking, it depends what else we got going. I mean, I think Rich said having our business model pretty closely which is in the components business, trying to find ways to do same things for less money or do mor
componenttext: It really depends I think on -- this is Tom speaking, it depends what else we got going. I mean, I think Rich said having our business model pretty closely which is in the components business, trying to find ways to do same things for less money or do more for the same money and without it, that's essentially what new products mean. And without it, we don't get to be the supplier and then what we have to do is come up with things or new capabilities, new features, new something in order to make sure that we have revenue growth. And we've been able to do that for the last 15 years in the Components business by finding new markets to go to, new products to add, new systems to go. So if everything was status quo, it would have an impact on revenues. Of course, everything isn't status quo. For example, we just grew our business in China by 37%. So this is the kind of thing we're trying to do is to offset sales revenue declines driven by cost savings, which don't necessarily translate into margin dollar declines, but they do mean sales go down and other things so we can do for those customers so we can drives up.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can add one example on that. Next year, we'll look at India. As we go to the NS4 [ph] we'll be adding content there doing both the aftertreatment and a fuel system, replacing existing supplier. That's example of step function changes when you have em
componenttext: If I can add one example on that. Next year, we'll look at India. As we go to the NS4 [ph] we'll be adding content there doing both the aftertreatment and a fuel system, replacing existing supplier. That's example of step function changes when you have emissions changes.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about your market share in heavy-duty truck in North America? It picked up sequentially, but you didn't change full year expectation. Can you just give us a little more color on what was happening during the quarter? Is it just a lumpy o
componenttext: Can you just talk about your market share in heavy-duty truck in North America? It picked up sequentially, but you didn't change full year expectation. Can you just give us a little more color on what was happening during the quarter? Is it just a lumpy order? And how do you expect that share to trend in 2017?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our share is the production share. So it's a share of the trucks built in any given quarter. And our share is high with a couple OEs and not so high with a couple others use their own engine. And so in Q3, we saw a couple, the ones who are low users of Cu
componenttext: Our share is the production share. So it's a share of the trucks built in any given quarter. And our share is high with a couple OEs and not so high with a couple others use their own engine. And so in Q3, we saw a couple, the ones who are low users of Cummins took their production down, which took our percent up. So that was the reason for kind of the step function. I think we were close to 35% in Q3. Having said that, we're gaining share in the market in a lot of places. We're virtually every mix fleet customer that we talked to using multiple engines, they're increasing their share with Cummins now, which we couldn't say 2 years ago. So I think some base improvement is going on. So I think the big step up we saw in Q3 was more of production cycle is changing and which OEs are taking down weeks versus expanding production.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful, and then can you remind us what the posturing is of that OEM involved in this loss contingency situation as we head into the commercial discussion?
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful, and then can you remind us what the posturing is of that OEM involved in this loss contingency situation as we head into the commercial discussion?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Well, let's see if I answer that question. You can do a follow-up if I missed it. So we're in dispute who pays for this. So that's where disagreement is. Quite frankly, on everything else -- and we've separated that and said we're going to resolve that separately. We know what the amount is. Both companies have accrued for that and we'll run through a process to resolve result what that final amount is. Everything else, we're moving ahead with and how we grow the business and move ahead and posturing is let's separate that. We've agreed to disagree and going to resolve it and everything else is going in the marketplace.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So they have agreed to disagree, just work it out later and yes, you'll get some recoveries sort of needs to be adjudicated in some way.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask about the China market share. It sounds like you're going to be down slightly this year. What's going on? I mean, is getting more aggressive in pricing? Are you actually relinquishing shares of Foton? Or is this just a pure customer mix
componenttext: I just want to ask about the China market share. It sounds like you're going to be down slightly this year. What's going on? I mean, is getting more aggressive in pricing? Are you actually relinquishing shares of Foton? Or is this just a pure customer mix issue of certain Chinese OEMs growing faster than others causing your share to move around?

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the latter, which is that there's just different customers gaining share. Again, there's been discounting in the market. The share was lost by some and went to gain some back our customers, with Foton, we are gaining share. I talked about some of the
componenttext: It's the latter, which is that there's just different customers gaining share. Again, there's been discounting in the market. The share was lost by some and went to gain some back our customers, with Foton, we are gaining share. I talked about some of the numbers there. Our ISG is doing well in the market. With Dongfeng, we're maintaining shares we're not losing anything there. In fact, despite all the predictions, we're just as strong as we've ever been with them. And so I feel really good about our position. I also feel really good about those OEMs. Those 2 OEMs are building quality product, meeting new emissions targets, and I believe that they will restore the share they're losing. It's during last year, Dongfeng in particular, has lost little bit of share while the others through some improvement in the products, too. Not just from discounting but they did take some old products and finally launched some new products. So by the way, never going to stop. But our product is both competitive from performance and cost point of view in China.

headline: Cummins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
